p: The genus Kniphofia belongs to the family Asphodelaceae which comprises 70 species mainly confined to Africa [ 12]. Fifteen of these species have been recorded in Eastern Africa, of which five including Kniphofia foliosa are endemic to Ethiopia [ 13, 14]. The rhizomes of K. foliosa are traditionally used for the treatment of abdominal cramps, malaria and wounds [ 15]. Previously, six in vitro active anti-malarial compounds were isolated from roots of K. foliosa by Wube et al . [ 16] and Abdissa et al . [ 17]. In continuation of search for lead anti-malarial compounds from Ethiopian medicinal plants [ 18– 20], the in vivo anti-malarial activity of the rhizomes of K. foliosa and its constituents are investigated.
